These combos are easier combos to supplement Hyde's missions.
 Some require the use of delayed rekkas (\@214A@ or \@214B@), a key part of his combo structure.
 If you can't do that yet, end those combos there.

Good balance between damage and corner carry. Buffer the dash so that Hyde starts running as he lands. You can do this by double tapping and then holding forward while Hyde is in the air after pressing Aerial\@6C@.

\@2A@ can be replaced with any normal into \@2C@ for more damage. \@22A@ into \@3B@ is a tricky link at first, but essential in Hyde's corner combos. If you can do it, you'll be well on your way to learning other corner combos.

Works anywhere, and off of any normal (except \@2A@, \@6B@ & \@3C@). Delayed rekkas are the backbone of many of Hyde's combos. Once you can delay rekkas consistently, make learning this route a priority. \@A@ or \@B@ rekkas work.
Basic \@6B@ combo at midscreen. \@A@ or \@B@ rekkas work.

The \@22A@ link can be a bit tricky at first, but this is a very strong combo that is relatively easy. You can also use both hits of \@6B@ and skip increase \@C@ for more damage. \@B+C@ is also optional if you want to save GRD.

Easy anti-air combo. The whiff \@2A@ rebeat is key in combo routing off an anti-air \@3C@. Making \@2A@ miss instead of waiting \@3C@ to end means it's easier to land a hit before the opponent hits the ground and is able to tech.
Basic anti-air combo on non-counter hits. Jump cancel must be a neutral jump. Forward jumping can make 66C cross up.

\@236A@ or \@B@ followup \@6A@ is one of Hyde's best moves, so being able to convert a hit into a combo is extremely useful. If you're new, don't worry about delaying the rekkas and end the combo there.

Great for starting pressure since \@236C@ allows you to approach safely on block. \@22A@ is one Hyde's best pokes, but can't be converted into a combo outside of the corner without meter or chain shift.
These are Wagner combos from the pinned Wagner doc by Vais.
High damage\@5A@ starter BnB. Also works with \@2A@.
Corner\@5C@ starter generic meter ender. Can also do \@22C@ \@236B@ > \@B@ J \@2C@   non vorpal for better oki (+20) but only shield buff and a loss of 63 damage.
These are Mika combos from the pinned Mika doc by Vegas Orb Enjoyer.
Starter is anything. This combo uses \@2A@ \@2A@ for example. \@236B@ delay is optional but without delay it will sideswap. More notes on the doc.
Good starter means any \@B@ normal \@C@ normal \@66B@ and counter hit normals.
Basic metered anti-air combo midscreen variation.
Bad Starter corner combo variation 1. Uses Force Function to deal more damage but costs more GRD.
Bad Starter corner combo variation 2. Has an alternative ender that doesn't use FF which saves GRD.

Good starter means any \@B@ normal \@C@ normal \@66B@ and counter hit normals. It's possible to do 3B instead of TK j.236A but it loses on damage. The trick is to try to do the TK when the hitstun from the starter ends. Otherwise the recovery frames will stop you from doing TK properly.
Basic anti-air combo corner variation. Unlike the midscreen version this one does not require meter. The first jump cancel in this REQUIRES it to be directly up (8).
These are newer Hilda combos for UNI2 by a-chan.
Midscreen bad starter. Can do \@2A@ up to 3 times. Slightly more damaging route. There is a slight meter focused route on the doc.
Corner bad starter. Can do \@2A@ up to 3 times.
Corner \@B@ starter. After 3B, you have to jump vertically (8) otherwise the combo will drop.
Max damage \@iJC@ starter. You'll have to back up a little farther than backdash range so that j.[C] will connect with 236B.
These are Tsurugi combos from the pinned Tsurugi doc by RedSlasher.
Optimal midscreen \@A@ starter combo. Omit the \@J236EX@ for meterless version.
These are Londrekia combos from the pinned Londrekia doc by Tukibito.
This combo starts from an attack with a fast startup. \nDrive the opponent away and go on the offensive.
This combo starts from a neutral poke attack. \nDrive the opponent away and go on the offensive.
This combo starts from a neutral poke attack. \nTurn your main neutral attacks into significant damage.
This combo starts from a neutral poke attack. \nUse EX special attacks to deal significant damage.
This combo starts from a neutral poke attack. \nUse Infinite Worth to deal significant damage.
This aerial combo works on airborne opponents. \nIt can deal significant damage.
This combo starts from an attack with a fast startup. \nTry this after blocking your opponent's attack.
This combo starts from Assault. \nYou can catch the opponent off-guard with a surprise overhead attack.
This combo starts from a neutral poke attack. \nTurn your main neutral attacks into significant damage.
This combo starts from an overhead attack. \nBreak through a crouching opponent's guard to deal significant damage.
This combo starts from a low attack. \nBreak through a standing opponent's guard to deal significant damage.
Use this combo after mixing up your opponent's guard \nby moving behind them and reversing their guard direction.
This combo starts from a throw. \nYou can mix up the opponent's guard to deal significant damage.
This combo starts from a command throw. \nYou can mix up the opponent's guard to deal significant damage.
Use this combo after guarding an attack that leaves your opponent wide open.
Use your EXS gauge to deal significant damage.
This combo uses Cross Cast Veil Off to increase damage.
This combo uses Cross Cast Veil Off when HP is low to increase damage.
This combo uses attack sequences that create gaps \nso that you can frame trap your opponent.
Deal significant damage after deflecting your opponent's jump-in attack.
This combo starts from a well-timed reversal against your opponent's attack. \nUse it when you have a good read on their attack timing!
This combo hits your opponent with Veil Off. \nYou can end your opponent's Vorpal state.
An explanation of main special attacks.
An explanation of basic combat strategy.
This combo switches your character's side with your opponent's. \nUse this when your back is against the wall to turn the tables \nand put your opponent in the corner instead!
This combo carries your opponent far across the stage. \nYou can carry them into the corner to gain an advantage.
This combo hits your opponent while avoiding their throw attempt.
This combo starts from trap setups.

\@Z@Increase　/　\@Y@Chain Shift　/　\@X@Jump Cancel\n
\@W@Hold　/　\@V@Delay　/　\@U@Veil Off\n
\@T@Cross Cast Veil Off

In the \cFFCD40Novice Course,\cX new players\n
will learn the \c40FFCDmain objectives and controls\cX for the game.\n
This is where you'll learn how to deal damage to your opponent ― and much more.

Congratulations on completing the Novice Course!\nOnce you're familiar with the basic controls, try your hand at Arcade Mode,\nor proceed to the Beginner Course to learn mechanics specific to fighting games.

In the \cFFCD40Beginner Course,\cX fighting game beginners will learn about\n
\c40FFCDvarious mechanics and rules specific to fighting games.\cX
Congratulations on completing the Beginner Course!\nIf you've come this far, you're really catching on to fighting games!\nHead over to the Intermediate Course to learn more challenging tactics.

In the \cFFCD40Intermediate Course,\cX we'll focus on \c40FFCDstrong moves that are useful in battle.\cX\n
You'll learn the core principles of offense and defense in fighting games.
Congratulations on completing the Intermediate Course!\nYou are now a bona fide fighting gamer!\nProceed to the Advanced Course to reach even greater heights.

The \cFFCD40Advanced Course\cX is designed for confident fighting game players\nwho wish to learn \c40FFCDtechniques specific to this game.\cX\nTake on each challenge one by one, as many of them are difficult.

Congratulations on completing the Advanced Course!\n If you made it this far, you're a fighting game master!\n
If you're aiming to play at a professional level, check out the Expert Course.
The \cFFCD40Expert Course\cX is designed for confident players who want to learn \n\c40FFCDdetailed mechanics and techniques that they can use in real matches\cX.
Congratulations on completing the Expert Course! You are officially an adept UNI player!\nNow go test your new skills in Versus and Network Modes!
This tutorial explains\cFFCD40 how to look at the game screen\cX.\nFamiliarize yourself with 1P and 2P sides and each of their gauges so that you \c40FFCDdon't miss any important details\cX.
This tutorial explains how to \cFFCD40move your character.\cX \nMoving toward or away from the opponent is the most basic, \nyet \c40FFCDmost important, mechanic.\cX
This tutorial explains \cFFCD40attacks.\cX\nFamiliarize yourself with various attacks and their merits\nto learn how to \c40FFCDdeal damage to your opponent\cX properly.

This tutorial explains \cFFCD40special attacks.\cX\n
Special attacks are performed via command inputs,\n
and they can be \c40FFCDvery powerful,\cX so be sure to master them!

This tutorial goes over the techniques necessary to perform \cFFCD40combos.\cX\n
Once you master combos, you can \c40FFCDdeal a lot of damage to your opponents\n
efficiently.\cX Learn how combos work and how to execute them.

This tutorial explains how to \cFFCD40guard\cX against an opponent's attack.\n
Guarding can \c40FFCDnullify any damage, no matter how strong the attack you're\n
defending against is.\cX Learn how to guard properly to avoid taking damage.

This tutorial explains how to break through your opponent's guard using\n
\cFFCD40throws.\cX Throwing is the best way to \c40FFCDbreak through an opponent's guard.\cX

This tutorial explains\cFFCD40 more ways to break an opponent's guard\cX\n
other than throwing. Learn various \c40FFCDmix-up techniques and how to counter them.\cX
This tutorial explains how to perform \cFFCD40block strings\cX that keep your opponent in a continuous guarding state.
This tutorial explains how to \cFFCD40interrupt\cX your opponent's offense.
This tutorial explains how to \cFFCD40recover\cX from a hit to avoid \ntaking additional damage.

This tutorial explains how to perform \cFFCD40Okizeme\cX against your opponent \nas they recover or stand up from being knocked down.\nLearn how \c40FFCDOkizeme works offensively\cX and how to counter it.
This tutorial explains the \cFFCD40GRD Gauge\cX that shows who has the upper hand \nin a match.
This tutorial explains how to avoid damage using \cFFCD40Shield\cX.
This tutorial explains how to use \cFFCD40Chain Shift\cX during Vorpal \nto deal massive damage.

This tutorial explains a comeback mechanic called \cFFCD40Veil Off\cX.\n
Going into the Veil Off state will grant you \c40FFCDopportunities \n
to deal massive damage.\cX
This tutorial explains \cFFCD40detailed rules\cX that apply under special conditions.\nFamiliarize yourself with the rules related to \c40FFCDtime limits and draws\cX.

This tutorial explains \cFFCD40command input technique.\cX\n
Here, you will learn how to execute complex commands like \@236+A@ \n
and \@623+A@.
